sections.heading: FROM MALDIVES FAMILY COURT:
sections.quote: The biggest and most common cause of divorce we see is lack of communication. People not having conversations that need to be had. Many discussions should have been had BEFORE marriage.

sections.heading: THE PROBLEM:
items: Not discussing important topics before marriage
'When you're in love, talking about these things isn't appropriate'

sections.heading: THE REALITY:
items: 'We'll figure it out' becomes 'Why didn't we discuss this?!'
Couples who discuss everything before marriage have stronger, happier marriages

slides.title: IF YOU CAN'T COMMUNICATE BEFORE MARRIAGE...

sections.heading: TRUTH:
sections.content: If you can't have these conversations BEFORE marriage when everything is romantic and hopeful...

sections.heading: You definitely won't be able to have them DURING marriage when:

slides.footer: Communication skills learned NOW = Foundation for entire marriage

sections.heading: YOU WILL:
items: Learn how to communicate (active listening, 'I' statements, PAUSE technique)
Discuss 15 essential topics that couples must agree on
Make joint decisions on major life areas
Identify where you agree (and where you don't)
Know what to put in your marital agreement

sections.heading: BY THE END:
items: You'll have discussed every major life decision
You'll know how to handle disagreements
You'll have communication framework for life together

slides.title: ACTIVE LISTENING

sections.heading: NOT Active Listening:
items: Waiting for your turn to talk

slides.footer: Goal: Make your partner feel HEARD

slides.title: "YOU" STATEMENTS vs "I" STATEMENTS
slides.formula: I feel [emotion] when [situation] because [reason]. I need [request].

slides.title: WHEN EMOTIONS GET TOO HIGH
slides.warningSignsHeading: Warning Signs You Need a Break:

technique.text: Set time to return ('Let's talk in 1 hour')

intro.question: What is Empathy?
intro.answer: 'Understanding how your partner feels, even if you don't agree'

example.title: Example: Money
scenarios: One partner saves every rufiyaa (grew up poor)
Other spends freely (never worried about money)
example.conclusion: Both are valid based on their experience!

slides.title: PRACTICE: CONVERT TO "I" STATEMENTS
slides.subtitle: Transform these 'You' statements:

exercises.template: I feel _______ when I'm talking and you're on your phone because _______. I need _______.
I feel _______ when we have plans and I wait because _______. I need _______.

slides.helpText: Feelings words to help: worried, hurt, frustrated, lonely, overwhelmed, scared, disappointed, unimportant

slides.title: PRACTICE SCENARIO: THE PHONE ISSUE
slides.scenario: Partner A feels hurt because Partner B is always on their phone during dinner.

sections.heading: BAD RESPONSE:
sections.content: 'You never pay attention to me! You care more about your phone than me!'

sections.heading: GOOD RESPONSE (I Statement):
sections.content: 'I feel lonely when we're at dinner and you're on your phone, because I want us to connect. I need us to have phone-free dinners together.'

sections.heading: ACTIVE LISTENING RESPONSE:
sections.content: 'I hear that you feel lonely at dinner when I'm on my phone. You're right - this is our time together. Let's both put phones away during meals.'

sections.heading: THE MISTAKE:
sections.content: Assuming you both want the same things without actually discussing them.

sections.heading: WHAT HAPPENS:
items: Partner A assumes they'll have 5 children

sections.heading: THE SOLUTION:
sections.content: DISCUSS EVERYTHING NOW. Even if it feels awkward.

slides.title: NOW: THE 15 ESSENTIAL DISCUSSIONS
slides.intro: From Maldives Family Court and focus groups with married/divorced couples, these are the topics that MUST be discussed before marriage.

slides.title: THE 15 ESSENTIAL TOPICS
slides.intro: These are the conversations that matter:
topics: 1. Children - Do we want them? When? How many?
2. Financial Management - How will we handle money?
3. Living Location - Where will we live?
6. Family Boundaries - How involved will families be?
7. Decision-Making - How do we decide things together?
8. Household Responsibilities - Who does what at home?
9. Religious Practices - What are our expectations?
10. Health Disclosure - Any conditions to share?
11. Conflict Resolution - How will we handle fights?
12. Future Contingencies - What if situations change?
13. Life Goals - What do we want to achieve?
15. Communication Agreement - Our ongoing communication plan
